"""http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090430/ap_on_he_me/med_swine_flu By MARK STEVENSON and ANDREW O. SELSKY, Associated Press Writers Mark Stevenson And Andrew O. Selsky, Associated Press Writers – 1 hr 24 mins ago MEXICO CITY – Mexico took even more drastic action to squelch a swine flu epidemic, ordering a suspension of private business activity and nonessential federal government activities, as the World Health Organization ratcheted up an alert, warning that "all of humanity" is threatened. The dire warning showed that world health officials are very worried about the potential for massive numbers of deaths worldwide from the mutated virus, even though the epidemic so far has claimed only a confirmed eight lives in Mexico and one in the United States. Roughly 170 deaths are suspected of having been caused by the virus in Mexico. Switzerland on Thursday became the latest country to report a swine flu infection — a 19-year-old student who health officials said was mistakenly released from a hospital and then hastily readmitted. European Union health ministers planned emergency talks in Luxembourg to coordinate national efforts in preventing the spread of swine flu in Europe. The Phase 5 alert, indicating a pandemic could be imminent as the virus spread further in Europe, prompted Mexico to announce the partial May 1-5 shutdown, Mexican Health Secretary Jose Cordova said late Wednesday

content: Fort Worth has shut down thier school system now.. Swine Flu Confirmed; FWISD Closes All SchoolsFORT WORTH (CBS 11 News) ― Centers for Disease Control World Health Organization Wednesday night officials with the Fort Worth Independent School District announced that all schools in the district will be closed beginning Thursday, April 30. "I want to let the public know that as of just a short while ago, it is the best advice and recommendation to me that we shut down the entire Fort Worth ISD beginning tomorrow," said Fort Worth ISD Superintendent Melody Johnson. "We will be shut down as an entire school system and we will have only essential personnel on duty in the central office." School district and health department officials say this is not a decision they made lightly. Officials say the decision came after recommendations from various health agencies and was necessary to help stop the spread of swine flu. Action was taken after the Center for Disease Control confirmed that a 12-year-old student at McLean Middle School has the new strain of the swine flu

content: Dave, the horses may be out of the barn, but they're in the corrals now. They are trying to stop the sick ones from getting out onto the open prairie now. This virus has a short life outside the body, it needs to stay moist. If people who are sick stay home, they have little chance of infecting many people. If the healty stay home there may be little chance of being infected. Thankfully the virus has a short span from infecting a person to the person no longer being infectious. They may feel like crap, but they cannot pass the virus on.

content: Absolutely right, sgt_posty, and a great analogy. Keeping people from mixing with other people any more than absolutely necessary for a short period (about two weeks) to break the cycle of transmission can cut disease transmission off at the knees. That means schools, sporting events, churches, rallies, town meetings - anything where crowds of people gather. I'd avoid the mall like crazy, and try to stock up on food to avoid frequent trips to the grocery store.
